repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
There are functions for setting the highlight namespace (`nvim_set_hl_ns`, `nvim_win_set_hl_ns`), but no way to retrieve what has been set. The update in this PR adds functions `nvim_get_hl_ns` and `nvim_win_get_hl_ns` to get the values that have been set.

Close #24309

comment_data.body:
wow thanks for working on! (though i failed to find any discussions on that issus from the dev team, are the demands in that issue even valid? anyway)
IMHO `return 0` has an ambiguous meaning: zero could be the global ns in other apis, and `win->w_ns_hl` could be zero(? nvim_win_set_hl_ns(winid, 0)` works with no error on my side), but here it represents 'window not found'.

An error will result from the call to `find_window_by_handle`. For example, an error is thrown when I call `:echo nvim_win_get_hl_ns(999999)`:
```
E5555: API call: Invalid window id: 999999
0
```
In the case of an error, it seems the return value loses its relevance. In this case, using `-1` would have a similar problem, as `nvim_win_set_hl_ns` also takes `-1` as a valid input value.

just a random though
if we see 0 as the global namespace it makes sense imo to just assume that the global namespace is used when you aren't able to get a specific one for the window used

This can take `opt` arg which optionally accepts a `win` key. Don't need the `nvim_win_*` variant.

This also seems to be another case where we didn't future-proof `nvim_get_namespaces()`.

Should this instead be named `nvim_get_ns()` and take an `opt` that controls the results? Why is "highlight" namespaces special enough to need a dedicated function? cc @bfredl 

```suggestion
nvim_get_ns({opt})                                            *nvim_get_ns()*

Parameters:
  {opt} Dict with optional keys:
    - "hl": include highlight namespaces
    - "win": only get window-local namespaces for this window-id
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -976,6 +976,12 @@ nvim_get_hl_id_by_name({name})                      *nvim_get_hl_id_by_name()*
 
     similar to |hlID()|, but allocates a new ID if not present.
 
+nvim_get_hl_ns()                                            *nvim_get_hl_ns()*

comment_data.body:
> "This can take opt arg which optionally accepts a win key. Don't need the nvim_win_* variant."

Two downsides are:

1) This would be inconsistent with `nvim_win_set_hl_ns` and `nvim_set_hl_ns`, where there are two separate functions.
2) There is a slight difference in the permitted return values. In the case for windows, the function can return `-1`, as that is the default value and is permitted by `nvim_win_set_hl_ns`. This is not the case for `nvim_set_hl_ns`.

Are these downsides okay as-is, outweighed by the benefit of using a single function? For downside 2, the documentation can state the difference. Regarding downside 1, based on the text under `:help api-contract`, I believe it's too late to merge `nvim_win_set_hl_ns` and `nvim_set_hl_ns` so that it would be consistent with a single `get` function.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -976,6 +976,12 @@ nvim_get_hl_id_by_name({name})                      *nvim_get_hl_id_by_name()*
 
     similar to |hlID()|, but allocates a new ID if not present.
 
+nvim_get_hl_ns()                                            *nvim_get_hl_ns()*

comment_data.body:
>  This would be inconsistent with `nvim_win_set_hl_ns` and `nvim_set_hl_ns`,

We'll fix that eventually. We need to stop the `nvim_buf` and `nvim_win` stuff, it was a mistake.

> There is a slight difference in the permitted return values. In the case for windows, the function can return -1, as that is the default value and is permitted by nvim_win_set_hl_ns. This is not the case for nvim_set_hl_ns.

If the caller passes `opt.win`, they should expect the behavior they opted-into.

> based on the text under :help api-contract, I believe it's too late to merge nvim_win_set_hl_ns and nvim_set_hl_ns so that it would be consistent with a single get function.

Yes, but we could introduce `nvim_set_ns`.

But I'm not certain it makes sense for "highlight namespaces" to be grouped with "general namespaces". Need others to comment on that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -976,6 +976,12 @@ nvim_get_hl_id_by_name({name})                      *nvim_get_hl_id_by_name()*
 
     similar to |hlID()|, but allocates a new ID if not present.
 
+nvim_get_hl_ns()                                            *nvim_get_hl_ns()*

comment_data.body: I don't understand why highlight namespaces exist at all. Couldn't we just use regular namespaces for highlights? If so perhaps we can retrofit this somehow and deprecate window namespaces?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -976,6 +976,12 @@ nvim_get_hl_id_by_name({name})                      *nvim_get_hl_id_by_name()*
 
     similar to |hlID()|, but allocates a new ID if not present.
 
+nvim_get_hl_ns()                                            *nvim_get_hl_ns()*

comment_data.body:
> "This can take opt arg which optionally accepts a win key. Don't need the nvim_win_* variant."

I've updated to code to now have a single function `nvim_get_hl_ns` that optionally accepts a `winid`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -976,6 +976,12 @@ nvim_get_hl_id_by_name({name})                      *nvim_get_hl_id_by_name()*
 
     similar to |hlID()|, but allocates a new ID if not present.
 
+nvim_get_hl_ns()                                            *nvim_get_hl_ns()*

comment_regular_data.body:
I think it should be `nvim_get_ns({opt})` until we hear an argument about why highlight namespaces need their own special functions.

This would deprecate `nvim_get_namespaces()`

> "I think it should be nvim_get_ns({opt}) until we hear an argument about why highlight namespaces need their own special functions."

I've renamed `nvim_get_hl_ns` to `nvim_get_ns`.
LGTM. Tried to rebase but github is having a bad morning, so rebased as a separate PR https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25455

title: feat(ui): allow to get the highlight namespace
